entries.def-search: a be call called give name nominate oneself to

senses.comment: In PF, this verb used to take a double accusative, but this usage disappeared early on in UF, with the second accusative, denoting the name, naturally being replaced by the absolutive, likely to avoid ambiguity that was starting to manifest as a result of UF’s increasingly free word order.
senses.def: +acc and abs To call, name, nominate, give a name to.
examples: <uf-s>Snet’h v.2</uf-s> <uf-w>jdap rác’hsaý’adâ</uf-w> ‘I call you a liar’; even in the writings of <uf-s>Snet’h</uf-s>, the double accusative is no longer attested.

senses.comment: Replaced by <uf-w>nvẹ́</uf-w> in Early Modern UF in the reflexive sense.

senses.comment: Originally, this idiom did not take a double <uf-s>acc</uf-s>, but was instead formed with the <uf-s>acc</uf-s> of ‘tree’ and the <uf-s>ill</uf-s> of the object, meaning something along the lines of ‘to bring down the tree(s) on sth’—the image here being that of cutting down trees in a wood until only a clearing remains or is ‘brought to light’.

entries.etym: from earlier <uf-w>Réáb’h</uf-w>; presumably the name of some celebrity or local deity

senses.comment: Main god of the ULTRAFRENCH pantheon; usually male. Old-fashioned also often all-caps <uf-w>RÁB’H</uf-w>.
examples: <uf-s>Snet’h</uf-s>, <uf-s>i.17</uf-s>: <uf-w>au lebálá daú RÁB’H</uf-w> ‘and thus spake Ráb’h’.

senses.comment: Used for <uf-sense>1</uf-sense> in all other cases; as with all names, only <uf-w>sénýr</uf-w> is inflected. Old-fashioned often <uf-w>RÁB’H Sénýr</uf-w>.
examples: <uf-s>Snet’h</uf-s>, <uf-s>8.1</uf-s>: <uf-w>au labraúc RÁB’H naút B’héhénýr</uf-w> ‘and they came to our Lord Ráb’h’.

senses.comment: Only attested figuratively. Not capitalised in this sense, and declined like a regular word.

examples: <uf-s>Snet’h</uf-s>, <uf-s>ii.3</uf-s>: <uf-w>ledéraújá’z derévôt’he láréáb’h</uf-w> ‘their god demanded they return’.
